The following formula determines the virtual index
, the location  of the quantile in the sorted sample:
i + g = q * ( n - alpha - beta + 1 ) + alpha
The different methods then work as follows

method 3 of H&F .     This method gives discontinuous results:

Input array or object that can be converted to an array.
Quantile or sequence of quantiles to compute, which must be between 0 and 1 inclusive.
Axis or axes along which the quantiles are computed. The default is to compute the quantile(s) along a flattened version of the array.
Alternative output array in which to place the result. It must have the same shape and buffer length as the expected output, but the type (of the output) will be cast if necessary.
If True, then allow the input array
to be modified by intermediate calculations, to save memory. In this case, the contents of the input
after this function completes is undefined.

This parameter specifies the method to use for estimating the quantile.  There are many different methods, some unique to NumPy. See the notes for explanation.  The options sorted by their R type as summarized in the H&F paper  are:
The first three methods are discontinuous.  NumPy further defines the following discontinuous variations of the default 'linear' (7.) option:
This argument was previously called "interpolation" and only offered the "linear" default and last four options.
If this is set to True, the axes which are reduced are left in the result as dimensions with size one. With this option, the result will broadcast correctly against the original array
Deprecated name for the method keyword argument.
, then the result is a scalar. If multiple quantiles are given, first axis of the result corresponds to the quantiles. The other axes are the axes that remain after the reduction of
. If the input contains integers or floats smaller than
. Otherwise, the output data-type is the same as that of the input. If
is specified, that array is returned instead.
Compute the q-th quantile of the data along the specified axis.

m = np.quantile(a, 0.5, axis=0)
out = np.zeros_like(m)
np.quantile(a, 0.5, axis=0, out=out)
See also `numpy.percentile` for a visualization of most methods.
equivalent to quantile, but with q in the range [0, 100].

signature.value: (a, q, axis=None, out=None, overwrite_input=False, method='linear', keepdims=False, *, interpolation=None)
